slides.title: Configuring CostData Objects
slides.ocrText: Configuring CostData Objects

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe the CostData Gosu classes to be
used by the rating engine to flexibly build up
the cost entities

• Define a new CostData class

slides.title: CostData objects
slides.ocrText: CostData objects

slides.title: CostData objects
slides.originalNotes:
CostData objects
CostData objects are plain old Gosu objects (POGOs) created by the rating engine to assist in rating and to build up the cost entities- CostData objects are not maintained. Although the cost and transaction entities define what PolicyCenter maintains the database and describes the results of the rating, it is difficult to write code that directly modifies cost entities. There are subtle aspects to manage such as splitting and merging entities. This interacts with how the PolicyCenter tracks revised entities across effective time. For example, creating or removing additional slice dates or tracking changes are window mode changes.
slides.notes:
CostData objects

There are subtle aspects to manage such as splitting and merging entities. This interacts with how the PolicyCenter tracks revised entities across effective time. For example, creating or removing additional slice dates or tracking changes are window mode changes.

| CostData objects G

Rating engine CostData objects Cost entities Database

• CostData objects are POGOs that mirror every cost entity
• They allow the rating engine to flexibly build up cost entities during rating

• Atthe end, the CostData objects are merged, prorated and copied to actual cost
entities to be maintained.

slides.title: General properties and methods
slides.ocrText:
| General properties and methods Gi

• The CostData base class provides common financial fields which match the cost

delegate , such as standard, override, actual values for base and adjusted rate,
term amount, and prorated amount

• It also provides common methods used by the rating engine, such as:
* mergelfCostEqual()

* copyStandardColumnsToActualColumns()
* setRounding()

slides.originalNotes:
Define a new CostData class
More details about CostData classes are discussed in the following slides.

More details about CostData classes are discussed in the following slides.
slides.ocrText:
| Define a new CostData class

Gi

• For every cost subtype entity, create a CostData subclass

• CostData subclass name = CostEntityName + “Data” | eti |

« Example: PACostData, PersonalAutoCovCostData,

PersonalVehicleCovCostData
• Extend the abstract class CostData or its child classes for the line
« Add member variables to match columns on the cost entity

Add constructors
• Implement abstract properties and methods

* KeyValues()
* setSpecificFieldsOnCost()
* getVersionedCosts()

slides.title: Keys
slides.originalNotes:
KEYS
In normal entities, one entity is linked to another using a foreign while CostData objects to another object using a key. In the database column itself, a fixed ID is a numeric value. The PolicyCenter encapsulates the numeric value of the fixed ID and the object entity type into a key object. Think of the key object as a simple container for the FK. In the rating context a fixed ID Key object is the most important use of the key class. The PersonalAutoCovCostData class identifies the private variables of the key type, one for the coverage PersonalAutoCov and the other for the coverable PersonalVehicle-
slides.notes:

| Keys Gi

• CostData subclasses must define member variables to match the columns on their
corresponding cost entities
• Define a property that links to an entity instance such as key in a CostData class

* Set the key field with the Fixedid property of the entity instance

* new PersonalAutoCovCostData ( start, end, cov.Currency, RateCache, vehicle.Fixedid, cov.Fixedid )

slides.title: Constructors
slides.originalNotes:
Constructors
Guidewire Best Practices recommends that customers not running in MultiCurrency mode should still use the constructor with the currency argument for their CostData configurations. This will facilitate an easy transition when/if they decide to update the CostData configurations to support MultiCurrency in the future There are constructors that do not have a currency and/or rate cache as a parameter to support backward compatibility- For any type of constructor, you can always add more parameters to set the member variables, such as those in PersonalAutoCovCostData. construct(effDate : Date, expDate : Date, c Currency, rateCache PolicyPeriodFXRateCache, vehiclelDArg : Key, covlDArg : Key)
slides.notes:
Constructors
Guidewire Best Practices recommends that customers not running in MultiCurrency mode should still use the constructor with the currency argument for their CostData configurations. This will facilitate an easy transition when/if they decide to update the CostData configurations to support MultiCurrency in the future There are constructors that do not have a currency and/or rate cache as a parameter to support backward compatibility- For any type of constructor, you can always add more parameters to set the member variables, such as those in PersonalAutoCovCostData. construct(effDate : Date, expDate : Date, c Currency, rateCache PolicyPeriodFXRateCache, vehiclelDArg : Key, covlDArg : Key)

slides.title: Merging CostData objects
slides.originalNotes:
Merging CostData objects
After the rating engine generates CostData objects for each line of business, the abstract rating engine merges CostData objects with similar costs- The rating engine considers two CostData objects mergable if they satisfy the following criteria.
• They have different but adjacent date ranges. For example, the date ranges January 1 through March 15 (end of day) and March 16 through December 31
• They have the same price, i.e., the same value in the TermAmount property.
• They represent pricing for the same kind of cost for the same thing- For example, for a personal auto coverage CostData object will merge the CostData objects if the objects share the same coverage ID and vehicle ID- This may require checking multiple properties and even properties not directly on the object.

In the example above, each row represents one CostData object The CostData object for liability coverage for auto 1 already exists during the policy change transaction. The PolicyCenter merges the CostData objects of both the versions of the policy if they are on the same slice and for the same type of coverage. In this example, they are considered to be on the same slice.
slides.notes:

slides.title: J KeyValues()
slides.originalNotes:
KeyValues()
Each CostData class must help the rating engine determine whether two CostData objects are the same.. The KeyValues() function provides a list of values that collectively identifies which properties to compare for two CostData objects- Generally, that includes matching subtype-specific columns that uniquely identify the set of related costs and the object whose price is represented. NOTE: Do not confuse KeyValues with key objects that contain a numeric fixed ID value and an entity type. The fixed ID key objects define how CostData objects store a link to a revised object within the policy graph. Carefully consider how the KeyValues method is implemented . Errors in this method may corrupt rating data during the merge process.
slides.notes:
KeyValues()
Each CostData class must help the rating engine determine whether two CostData objects are the same.. The KeyValues() function provides a list of values that collectively identifies which properties to compare for two CostData objects- Generally, that includes matching subtype-specific columns that uniquely identify the set of related costs and the object whose price is represented. NOTE: Do not confuse KeyValues with key objects that contain a numeric fixed ID value and an entity type. The fixed ID key objects define how CostData objects store a link to a revised object within the policy graph. Carefully consider how the KeyValues method is implemented . Errors in this method may corrupt rating data during the merge process.

slides.title: setSpecificFieldsOnCost()
slides.originalNotes:
setSpecificFieIdsOnCost()
After a line of business creates its CostData objects, the abstract rating engine creates new cost entities or updates existing cost entities. Subtypes must implement the setSpecificFieldsOnCost() function to set any subtype- specific field on the newly- created (or pre-existing) cost entity that the CostData is being copied to. The CostData base class will manage the replication of all the common fields (e.g. amounts and rates)- This method populates any fields that are unique to this subtype, such as FKs to coverages values.
slides.notes:
setSpecificFieIdsOnCost()
After a line of business creates its CostData objects, the abstract rating engine creates new cost entities or updates existing cost entities. Subtypes must implement the setSpecificFieldsOnCost() function to set any subtype- specific field on the newly- created (or pre-existing) cost entity that the CostData is being copied to. The CostData base class will manage the replication of all the common fields (e.g. amounts and rates)- This method populates any fields that are unique to this subtype, such as FKs to coverages values.
slides.ocrText:
| setSpecificFieldsOnCost() G

* CostData subclasses must implement the setSpecificFieldsOnCost() method

« Used to create new cost entities or update existing cost entities based on
CostData objects

* CostData base class sets the general properties for the cost entity, such as
amounts and rates

• Subclasses must set the fields specific to the associated cost entities
• Non-FK properties: set properties directly on the cost entities

« FK properties: set properties using setFieldValue( costPropertyNames, Key )

costPropertyName: String specifying property name on av cost entity

Key: Key containing the fixedID for the object to be linked. Example:
cost.setFieldValue (“PersonalAutoCov”, _covID) in
PersonalAutoCovCostData.as

slides.title: Cost VersionList
slides.originalNotes:
Cost Version List
A Cost VersionList is a set of cost rows that represent the cost for the same thing. Each row represents a different date range, and the price for that date range. For example, for a PersonalAutoCovCostData object, the getVersionedCosts() method returns a version list that represents all of the PersonalAutoCovCost entity instances for the same vehicle.
slides.notes:
Cost Version List
A Cost VersionList is a set of cost rows that represent the cost for the same thing. Each row represents a different date range, and the price for that date range. For example, for a PersonalAutoCovCostData object, the getVersionedCosts() method returns a version list that represents all of the PersonalAutoCovCost entity instances for the same vehicle.

slides.title: getVersionedCosts()
slides.originalNotes:
getVersionedCosts()
This is the most complicated function that a CostData subclass must implement- It is complicated because it requires careful application of knowledge about the PolicyCenter revisioning system. The calling code expects to receive a list with only one version listed, or an empty list if no existing cost entities match this CostData object.
A general approach for the getVersionedCosts method is to first get a version list reference for the relevant object that has a cost. If the CostData class has an associated key member field, it is easy to use the key to find the matching version list.
slides.notes:
getVersionedCosts()
This is the most complicated function that a CostData subclass must implement- It is complicated because it requires careful application of knowledge about the PolicyCenter revisioning system. The calling code expects to receive a list with only one version listed, or an empty list if no existing cost entities match this CostData object.
A general approach for the getVersionedCosts method is to first get a version list reference for the relevant object that has a cost. If the CostData class has an associated key member field, it is easy to use the key to find the matching version list.
slides.ocrText:
| getVersionedCosts() Gi

* CostData subclasses must implement the getVersionedCosts() method
« Used to match corresponding costs to the CostData object
• Retrieve version lists of cost objects from the PolicyPeriod

• Repeat all costs for the target object and determine which cost entity instances
correspond to the current CostData object

• Use the Key field to match the cost if the CostData subclass has one

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What are CostData objects? How are they named?
•
•
SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

questionData.question: What are CostData objects? How are they named?
questionData.answer: CostData objects are Gosu objects that mirror every cost on a policy graph. Each CostData subclass has the same name as the cost entity followed by the suffix “Data”.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Describe briefly the two CostData constructors.
•
SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

questionData.question: Describe briefly the two CostData constructors.
questionData.answer:
The two CostData constructors are:
- Date-based constructor is created based on effective and expiration dates, usually for a new cost object.
+ Cost-based constructor is created based on a pre-existing cost object that is passed-in as a parameter.

slides.title: Knowledge Check

Question
Why are KeyValues needed?
•
SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

questionData.question: Why are KeyValues needed?
questionData.answer: KeyValues are needed to determine if two CostData objects are the same. The KeyValues property creates a list of the Key Values. The rating engine uses it as it merges CostData objects.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:

•
or KeyValues are needed to determine if two CostData objects are the same. The
KeyValues property creates a list of the Key Values. The rating engine uses it as it
merges CostData objects.

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
Why can you not set properties directly on cost entities for both FKs?
•
•
SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

questionData.question: Why can you not set properties directly on cost entities for both FKs?
questionData.answer:
For non-FK properties, you can set the properties directly on the cost entity instance.
For FK properties, this approach does not work, because CostData objects store the
entity's fixed ID encapsulated in a key object. So the methods
setSpecificFieldsOnCost and setFieldValue provided by the CostData class must be
used to set the foreign key properties.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
Why can you not set properties directly on cost entities for both FKs?
or For non-FK properties, you can set the properties directly on the cost entity instance.
For FK properties, this approach does not work, because CostData objects store the
entity's fixed ID encapsulated in a key object. So the methods
setSpecificFieldsOnCost and setFieldValue provided by the CostData class must be
used to set the foreign key properties.
SSS eee oe eo ooo e SoD
